chapter.title: Interceptors
chapter.para: Thanks to the managed bean specification, interceptors are now part of the core functionality of a bean. That means that you no longer need to make your class an EJB just to use interceptors!

But that doesn't mean there aren't other improvements that can be made. CDI builds on the interceptor architecture of managed beans by introducing a more sophisticated, semantic, annotation-based approach to binding interceptors to beans.

Interceptor functionality is defined in the interceptor specification, which the managed bean, CDI, and EJB specifications all support. The interceptor specification defines two kinds of interception points:
A business method interceptor applies to invocations of methods of the bean by clients of the bean:
A lifecycle callback interceptor applies to invocations of lifecycle callbacks by the container:
An interceptor class may intercept both lifecycle callbacks and business methods.

section.title: Interceptor bindings
section.para: Suppose we want to declare that some of our beans are transactional. The first thing we need is an interceptor binding annotation to specify exactly which beans we're interested in:
Now we can easily specify that our ShoppingCart is a transactional object:
section.programlisting: @Transactional public class ShoppingCart { ... }
section.para: Or, if we prefer, we can specify that just one method is transactional:

section.title: Implementing interceptors
section.para: That's great, but somewhere along the line we're going to have to actually implement the interceptor that provides this transaction management aspect. All we need to do is create a standard interceptor, and annotate it @Interceptor and @Transactional.
All bean interceptors are beans, and can take advantage of dependency injection and contextual lifecycle management.
Multiple interceptors may use the same interceptor binding type.

section.title: Enabling interceptors
section.para: By default, all interceptors are disabled. We need to enable our interceptor in the beans.xml descriptor of a bean deployment archive. This activation only applies to beans in the same archive.
section.programlisting: <beans xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation=" http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee/beans_1_0.xsd"> <interceptors> <class>org.mycompany.myapp.TransactionInterceptor</class> </interceptors> </beans>
section.para: Whoah! Why the angle bracket stew?
Well, have the XML declaration is actually a good thing. It solves two problems:

listitem.para: it enables us to specify a total ordering for all the interceptors in our system, ensuring deterministic behavior, and
it lets us enable or disable interceptor classes at deployment time.

section.para: For example, we could specify that our security interceptor runs before our transaction interceptor.
section.programlisting: <beans xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation=" http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee/beans_1_0.xsd"> <interceptors> <class>org.mycompany.myapp.SecurityInterceptor</class> <class>org.mycompany.myapp.TransactionInterceptor</class> </interceptors> </beans>
section.para: Or we could turn them both off in our test environment by simply taking no action! Ah, so simple.

section.para: Suppose we want to add some extra information to our @Transactional annotation:

Now we can use RequiresNewTransactionInterceptor like this:

section.title: Multiple interceptor binding annotations
section.para: Usually we use combinations of interceptor bindings types to bind multiple interceptors to a bean. For example, the following declaration would be used to bind TransactionInterceptor and SecurityInterceptor to the same bean:
section.programlisting: @Secure(rolesAllowed="admin") @Transactional public class ShoppingCart { ... }
section.para: However, in very complex cases, an interceptor itself may specify some combination of interceptor binding types:
section.programlisting: @Transactional @Secure @Interceptor public class TransactionalSecureInterceptor { ... }

section.title: Interceptor binding type inheritance
section.para: One limitation of the Java language support for annotations is the lack of annotation inheritance. Really, annotations should have reuse built in, to allow this kind of thing to work:
section.programlisting: public @interface Action extends Transactional, Secure { ... }
section.para: Well, fortunately, CDI works around this missing feature of Java. We may annotate one interceptor binding type with other interceptor binding types (termed a meta-annotation). The interceptor bindings are transitive — any bean with the first interceptor binding inherits the interceptor bindings declared as meta-annotations.
Now, any bean annotated @Action will be bound to both TransactionInterceptor and SecurityInterceptor. (And even TransactionalSecureInterceptor, if it exists.)

section.title: Use of @Interceptors
section.para: The @Interceptors annotation defined by the interceptor specification (and used by the managed bean and EJB specifications) is still supported in CDI.
However, this approach suffers the following drawbacks:

listitem.para: the interceptor implementation is hardcoded in business code,
interceptors may not be easily disabled at deployment time, and
the interceptor ordering is non-global — it is determined by the order in which interceptors are listed at the class level.

section.para: Therefore, we recommend the use of CDI-style interceptor bindings.
